title: The Secret Brilliance of Rotating Game modes (That I just realized)
body:
The official queue (For now) has been announced:

Ascension
Poro King
URF
Hexakill
One-For-All

One of the biggest problems with these modes is that they'd get stale after a week. People figure out a meta, pick the best stuff, etc. It's also why many people are pissy about URF being spread through the year rather than on a single two week period. I, in my infinite slowness, just realized why this is actually a fantastic thing. We'll have URF back about five weeks from now, or about a month and a half. You know what else we'll have in that time?

The mage reworks and maybe one extra patch.

This is the secret beauty of these patches. For a more immediate example, the last time we played ascension was two weeks ago. When Ascension comes back? Taric rework, mage items and all those mage updates will be on live. Holy crap, that completely changes the way we played Ascension from last time. THAT is why spreading game modes out is smart. Rather than giving us two weeks to completely adjust and form a slapdash meta, we're going to be playing these games in a different environment every time we play.

New champions. New Items. Reworks. Whatever have you, this drastically improves the lifespan of the game. Kudos to Riot, that's actually brilliant.

Looking at the other game modes, most champions didn't get balance updates for many of the other game modes, and there were very few, if any, extreme outliers for Riot to permaban from the mode (apart from URF and what modes I can't remember off the top of my head, the only game mode to permaban champions that I can remember was when One-for-All banned Teemo and Karthus).

The first time URF came around it started with bans to Ryze and Kassadin and balance changes to almost a half-dozen other champions and a few items. After a week of the mode being up the ban list tripled. The second time it came around, it rebalanced somewhere between a quarter to half the cast so as not to have any completely broken champions, yet it still had some rather extreme outliers. That's how much balance needs to go into URF, and yet it still remained rather unbalanced.

It's simply much better to have some content come out and have strategies from SR and then on occasion, we get to have fun with URF.
I'd rather not put myself in the situation where i'd say "URF is boring".

That's called growth.
Having Riot exercise your fancy is taking one step forward and ten steps back.

Riot doesn't want to make balance changes with respect to other game modes. How frequently do their patch notes make changes to game modes other than Summoner's Rift, or include buffs/nerfs because of the metas involved in other game modes? Without balance changes intended for URF the mode would stagnate. Anybody who remembers the first time we had URF likely remembers we had the same 6 bans and same 3-4 dominaring picks after a few days prior to the permabans. That was after a week, give us a month and we'd have full tier lists. 

ARAM works because it's random. Random locks, with rerolls, plus the Snowball summoner spell prevents stagnation while allowing variance. If we want URF permanently they'd have to add similar things just to keep us playing it. Even then I doubt ARAM and URF could coexist.
